node.text:
We must change and care for our planet.
And that change starts with education.
Let’s #LearnForOurPlanet to build a better future for all! 🌍
.
.
.
.
#Education #EducationForSustainableDevelopment #ESD #ClimateAction #ActOnClimate #ParisAgreement #ClimateChange #GlobalGoals #TogetherForOurPlanet #SustainableDevelopment #ActNow #SustainableDevelopmentGoals #SDGs #UNESCO #ClimateStrike #ChangingMindsNotTheClimate #GlobalWarming

node.text:
Culture and heritage are not a mere commodity.

As ethnic motifs become trendy, the world’s fast growing fashion market must respect the rights and interests of indigenous communities. 

Ahead of Thursday's #WorldArtDay, read the @unescocourier and learn more via link BIO 👆
.
.
.
.
#ShareCulture #Culture #IndigenousPeoples #WeAreIndigenous #UNESCO #UNSCOCourier

node.text:
the world witnessed the destruction of the 2 standing Bamiyan Buddhas in Afghanistan, tragically reducing history and cultural heritage of the world to rubble. 

The empty niches of the giant Buddhas in the Bamiyan Valley of Afghanistan are a perpetual reminder of our duty to protect cultural heritage, and what future generations stand to lose if we do not. 

Today, the area is considered by UNESCO a World Heritage Site in Danger. 
.
.
.
.
#UNESCO #ProtectHeritage #ShareOurHeritage #ShareCulture

Check the link in bio for more!
.
.
.
.

#IWD2021 #Journalists #ProtectJournalists #WomenJournalists #FreedomOfSpeech #PressFreedom #HumanRights

node.text:
It’s the Smurfs and they have an important message to share...

New research from @UNESCO’s latest report on marine World Heritage sites show they play a crucial role in mitigating Climate Change and meeting Paris Agreement targets.

The 50 marine sites on UNESCO's World Heritage List comprise at least 21% of the global area of blue carbon ecosystems and 15% of global blue carbon assets - carbon stores that are equivalent to about 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions in 2018.

Their protection plays a central role in storing carbon from the atmosphere. But degradation of these ecosystem can also release billions of tons of greenhouse gases.
.
.
.
.
#WorldHeritage #ClimateChange #ParisAgreement #UNESCO #ActNow

node.text:
Among the hardest hit are travel and tourism and culture.

The disruption of many intangible cultural practices will have heavy consequences for communities and those working in the performing arts and traditional crafts for years. 

Read the full story via the @unescocourier link in bio 👆
.
.
.
.
#UNESCO #UNESCOCourier #COVID19 #Culture #Tourism #RestartTourism #ShareCulture #UNESCO #UNESCOCourier #ShareOurHeritage

node.text:
This week marked the 76th anniversary of the liberation of the concentration and extermination camp of Auschwitz-Birkenau by Soviet troops.

The soldiers found around seven thousand emaciated detainees, many of whom perished in the following days. They saw the corpses of the sickest and weakest prisoners, executed after the Nazis forced the majority of the prisoners still alive to take part in a “death march” towards the west. They also discovered traces of the merciless system that the Nazis put in place, and the efforts they made to disguise it: destroyed files, damaged photographs and the remaining gas chambers.

Auschwitz-Birkenau was the most murderous killing centre and the largest concentration camp established by Nazi Germany during the Holocaust. It was here that over 1.1 million Jews and tens of thousands of Roma, Poles, Soviet prisoners-of-war and other persecuted populations lost their lives.

Today, as hateful voices continue to rise, denying or distorting the implacable reality of these facts, we have a universal responsibility to remember each and every individual whom the Nazis sought to erase from the face of the earth. We must remember the communities and cultures that were destroyed; we must care for historic sites; we must protect and preserve against attempts to spread the ideas that led to the genocide of Jewish people and other Nazi crimes, and that threaten the human rights of all.

The International Day of Commemoration in Memory of the Victims of the Holocaust is a time to mourn those who disappeared and to reflect upon the choices of the individuals and governments that allowed this genocide to unfold. It is also a call for vigilance and for action, to address the root causes of hatred and prevent future atrocities from happening.

.
.
.
.
#HolocaustRemembrance #HolocaustRemembranceDay #Auschwitz76 #Holocaust #HolocaustEducation
#Education #Shoah #ShoahMemorial #HolocaustMemorialDay #HolocaustMemorial #WeRemember #History #NeverForget #UNESCO #NeverAgain

.
.
.
.

node.text:
Salonga National Park in Democratic Republic of the Congo removed from the List of World Heritage in Danger due to improvements in its state of conservation!

Congratulations! 👏🎉👏🎉

The management of the park has been greatly improved and the regular monitoring of wildlife shows that bonobo populations remain stable in the property despite past pressures and that the forest elephant population has slowly begun recovering.

Inscribed in 1984 on the World Heritage List and in 1999 in the List of World Heritage in Danger, Salonga National Parkis Africa’s largest tropical rainforest reserve. Situated at the heart of the central basin of the Congo river, the park is very isolated and accessible only by water. It is the habitat of many endemic endangered species, such as the bonobo, the Congo peacock, the forest elephant and the African slender-snouted or 'false' crocodile.
.
.
.
.
.
.
Photo: The Bonobo (Pan paniscus), called the pygmy chimpanzee. Democratic Republic of Congo - ©️ Sergey Uryadnikov
.

node.text:
Nelson Mandela, one of the greatest moral & political leaders of our time was born on this day in 1918.

On #MandelaDay, join us as we pay tribute to this brave advocate of human rights, who taught the world the power of peace and reconciliation, and the importance of respect for the dignity of every human being.

Check out the The UNESCO Courier's special tribute and learn more about his extraordinary fight against #apartheid in South Africa (link via @UNESCOCourier's BIO)
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Fishermen from the Moken community, living on the Surin Islands in the Andaman Sea and off the west coast of Thailand, create artificial underwater reefs with palm leaves to lure fish.

At least 1/4 of the world’s land area is traditionally owned, managed, used or occupied by indigenous peoples. Although they are the ones who tend to find themselves on the front lines of environmental and social change, their knowledge is rarely taken into account by researchers and policy makers. 

Learn more about indigenous people as informed custodians of biodiversity in the latest issue of the UNESCO Courier. Link via @UNESCOCourier's BIO☝️
.
.
.
.
📸: ©️Sofie Olsen
.
.
.
.
.#UNESCO #UNESCOCourier #Biodiversity #ForNature #ClimateChange #Thailand #AndamanSea

node.text:
15 July is World Youth Skills Day!
🔨👩🏾‍🦰✂️👱🏿‍♀️📱👱🏽💻 🧑🏾‍🦱 🔬👩🏾‍🦱

Young people aged 15-24 are particularly exposed to the socio-economic consequences of the pandemic. School and workplace closures are leading to learning and training losses. Major life-cycle transitions are made difficult if not impossible, including graduation from general education or TVET, residential autonomy, and labour market insertion.

Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) has a key role to play in fostering the resilience of young people. It is crucial to ensure the continuity of skills development and to introduce training programmes to bridge skills gaps. Solutions need to be reimagined in a way that considers not only the realities of the present, but also the full range of possibilities for the future.
.
.
.
.
.
Photos : ©️UNESCO-UNEVOC (Skills in Action Photo Competition 2020) @unesco_unevoc 
.
#LearningNeverstops #Youth #Skills #Education #Training #COVID19 #TVET #VocationalTraining #Empowerment #Jobs #UNESCO #WYSD2021

node.text:
Today is Bastille Day, the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille prison in Paris on 14 July 1789, a turning point of the French Revolution that would give birth to a new nation of values and ideas rooted in liberty, equality, and fraternity.

The visionaries of the enlightenment period could not have foreseen the domino effect that democracy would have across the world, as “Liberty for all” became the motto of their time.

From the shores of France to the shores of San Domingo, the Enlightenment ideas would bloom many years later during the first successful anti-abolition and anti-colonial revolution led by self-liberated slaves against their oppressors. Herein, the idea of “man as a citizen” was born and a new era of dignity ignited. This great hope for universal fraternity became concrete when the declaration of human rights was adopted in 1948.

The influence of #BastilleDay forever defined our collective world. It truly became “An Idea that changed the world.”

#France #FrenchRevolution #History #OnThisDay #Liberty #Revolution #Democracy #HumanRights #Bastille #Freedom #Enlightenment #UNESCO #14Juillet

Painting: "The Storming of the Bastille", by Jean-Pierre Houël

node.text:
Here lies the SS Maheno, a New Zealand ocean liner  built in 1905 that operated in the Tasman Sea crossing between New Zealand and Australia. During the First World War she served as a hospital ship in the Mediterranean, Gallipoli, and the English Channel. SS Maheno became outdated and washed ashore on Fraser Island, Australia where she remains a popular tourist attraction. 

The conservation of this wreck,  witness of our common history depends only on us. Together, let’s take action to preserve our heritage and history. 
.
.
.
.
Photo ©Micheal Dawes 📸
.
.
.
.
. #UnderwaterHeritage #OceanDecade #UNESCO #History #ShareCulture #ShareOurHeritage #ProtectHeritage
